metadata.aiReasoning: The exercise primarily involves interpreting a tape diagram to understand the ratio of text to illustration area, not graphing or plotting points on a coordinate plane. The original problem does not seem to use or require a coordinate plane widget, instead using tape diagrams and numerical ratios. Thus, there is no coordinate plane data to extract or recreate, and the information is unrelated to widgets of this type. If a coordinate plane widget were required, it would involve a Cartesian plane setup with coordinates of points, lines, or polygons, none of which are part of the given content.

hints.content:
###Strategy

We can find the ratio of text area to illustration area by counting the equal parts of each in the tape diagram.

Then we can create an equivalent ratio by picking a number of square centimeters for each equal part in the diagram to represent $500\,\text{cm}^2$ of illustrations.

To make an equivalent ratio, we multiply each part of the ratio by the same number.

###Identify the given ratio

There are $\goldE{3\,\text{cm}^2}$ of text for every $\redE{2\,\text{cm}^2}$ of illustrations.

###Create an equivalent ratio

If each part represents $\purpleD{250\,\text{cm}^2}$, there will be $750\,\text{cm}^2$ of text, because $\goldE{3}\purpleD{\times 250} = 750$.

[[☃ image 1]]

If each part represents $\purpleD{250\,\text{cm}^2}$, there will be $500\,\text{cm}^2$ of illustrations, because $\redE{2}\purpleD{\times 250} = 500$.

options.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of unequal lengths. The first tape has 3 equal parts, each labeled 250. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled Text area. The second tape has 2 equal parts of the same size as in the first tape, each labeled 250.  A curved bracket below the second tape is labeled Illustration area.

hints.content: There are $750\,\text{cm}^2$ of text when there are $500\,\text{cm}^2$ of illustrations.

question.content:
An author is writing and illustrating a new book. The tape diagram represents the ratio of area, in $\text{cm}^2$, with text to area with illustrations.

[[☃ image 1]]

**Based on the ratio, what is the area of the text when there are $500\,\text{cm}^2$ of illustrations?**

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] $\text{cm}^2$

options.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of unequal lengths. The first tape has 3 equal parts. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled Text area. The second tape has 2 equal parts of the same size as in the first tape.  A curved bracket below the second tape is labeled Illustration area.
